awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying Controls on Weathering of Seafloor Massive Sulfides
awd_abstract_narration:
Venting of high temperature (up to 400°C) hydrothermal fluids into seawater in the deep ocean results in formation of metal-rich sulfide mineral deposits (seafloor massive sulfides or SMS).  These sulfides are analogous to some types of copper- and iron-rich ore deposits mined on land.  Current estimates are that there are approximately a billion metric tons of SMS present in close proximity to areas of seafloor spreading along mid-ocean ridges and in back-arc basins.  These deposits are a significant reservoir of both metals and energy that can be harnessed by microorganisms living in the dark at the seafloor.  This proposal focuses on determining the fate of these deposits, i.e., do SMS deposits weather (rust) completely, leaving behind only oxide minerals, or does early alteration create an impermeable layer that seals the surfaces, protecting the metal sulfide rich interiors from reaction with seawater? Understanding the fate of SMS is important because the deposits 1) could act as sources of energy for microbial life in the deep sea (through oxidation-reduction reactions) and 2) are eventually re-cycled into Earth?s interior and/or volcanic arc and back-arc systems when ocean crust is subducted. The project includes participation of a predominantly undergraduate institution and training of undergraduate students in the laboratory and at sea.

Seafloor massive sulfide (SMS) samples will be collected during six submersible dives on the Juan de Fuca Ridge off the coast of Washington.  Physical, chemical, and mineralogical properties of the samples (from fresh interiors to weathered exteriors) will be identified using petrography, scanning electron microscopy, micro-X-ray diffraction and synchrotron-based techniques.  The presence of major microbial groups will be identified through sequencing of DNA and RNA and mapping of fluorescently labeled microbial populations. These data will be incorporated into a reactive transport model to attain the following: (1) reproduce observed assemblages, (2) estimate pore fluid compositions, (3) calculate free energy yields of metabolic reactions, (4) test the hypothesis that porosity and extents of micro-fracturing control long-term susceptibility to weathering, (5) estimate time-scales of weathering, and (6) investigate the role of microbial activity in weathering. An enriched understanding of the controls on weathering of SMS will allow for improved predictions of the lifetime of metal-rich portions of deposits and the potential biomass supported by these reactions, as well as add to a growing understanding of the subsurface biosphere and its role in deep-sea carbon cycling.

por.por_cntn:
Seafloor massive sulfide deposits form along seafloor spreading centers (at mid-ocean ridges or in back-arc basins) as hot vent fluids exit the seafloor and mix with cold seawater. The vent fluids have a very different chemistry than seawater, having formed from interactions between seawater (that percolated into newly formed ocean crust and was heated) and ocean crustal rocks that solidified from magma. They are metal-rich compared to seawater, and contain the major sulfide minerals pyrite (iron disulfide), chalcopyrite (copper iron disulfide), and sphalerite (zinc sulfide). Deposit sizes range from a few meters diameter and height to mounds that stand ~50 meters high and are a few hundreds of meters in diameter.  The larger deposits are analogs of some types of economically viable volcanic-associated massive sulfide deposits found on land. This project focused on the fate of these deposits after hydrothermal activity has ceased, the extent to which they alter and weather and the mechanisms of the process, the exchange of elements between the deposits and the ocean during this weathering, and the extent to which this process can provide energy to deep sea organisms. 

To meet these objectives, seventeen samples of inactive seafloor massive sulfide, in various stages of weathering, were recovered in 2018, on cruise KM-18-12, using the remotely-operated vehicle ROV Jason 2. Samples were taken from inactive deposits located adjacent and distal to the currently active Main Endeavour Field on the Juan de Fuca Ridge, from several areas where venting ceased long ago. Quantitative documentation of evidence for oxidative weathering of reduced sulfide minerals was then done, focusing on the rinds of the samples where observed textures suggest significant variation in weathering rates. Five of the 17 samples, that range in size, putative age, crystallinity, and porosity, underwent detailed study. Porosity and rind thickness on these samples were determined via imaging of thin sections and analysis. Analysis was then done using a combination of X-ray Absorption Near Edge Spectroscopy (XANES), synchrotron-based X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF), and X-Ray Diffraction (XRD).  A total of 26 thin sections obtained from one to three regions per sample were analyzed and fit with a total of 298 XANES points to create comprehensive redox maps that detail the variation in both speciation and oxidation state of the elements in the alteration (oxidation) rinds of each sample, and allowed for characterization of the localized redox environment. 

Samples were found to contain reduced sulfides such as pyrite, pyrrhotite, mackinawite, marcasite, sphalerite, and chalcopyrite, as well as oxidized rinds comprised of Fe-oxides like ferrihydrite, feroxyhyte, and Fe-bearing clays (ferrosmectite). These maps document the initial (primary) and alteration (secondary) phases present, the distribution of weathering products at the sample surface and within pore features, and the associated trace metals (metals such as manganese and chromium, in addition to copper, zinc, and iron). These data constrain the fine-scale redox environments of seafloor massive sulfide deposits from the Endeavor segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge to a greater degree than previous work. This is a major step toward the ultimate goal of clarifying the causes of variation, elucidating the mechanisms by which alteration processes occur and the drivers that govern overall weathering processes. This information will allow improved predictions of the lifetime of these deposits, their potential as long- term metal reservoirs in the deep ocean, and a better understanding of the fate of sulfide-derived metals upon weathering. For example, repartitioning of metals within iron oxides has implications on their bioavailability to support deep sea and sulfide deposit-hosted life. Knowledge of the full suite of elements and their mobility after hydrothermal activity has ceased will aid understanding of a number of elemental cycles in the deep sea.

With recent interest in mining seafloor deposits, a better understanding of the composition and the fate of the deposits is of interest to mining companies, with high societal relevance to the developing countries within whose waters many of the deposits reside. This research project involved significant participation and training. Four graduate students were provided with sea-going experience and training in use of ROV Jason 2, and in shipboard subsampling techniques. Three graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher were trained in synchrotron-based analysis, including X-ray diffraction spectra collection, analysis, and interpretation. One graduate student was also trained in microscopic and image analysis of thin sections for quantifying porosity and rind thickness using the software ImageJ. Portions of the project will form a chapter of this student's thesis, and will be submitted shortly for publication. Metadata for all collected samples have been submitted to the System for Earth Sample Registration (SESAR) so that anyone can access information. Standard X-ray absorption spectra collected as part of this project were submitted to a standard spectra repository at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource, which is available to all users at US-based synchrotron facilities.
